content:
Introduction

Vaginal foreign bodies are objects that become lodged in the vaginal canal, either intentionally or unintentionally.  This condition is more common in pediatric patients due to a variety of causes ranging from accidental insertion to incomplete removal of foreign objects (eg, tampons, vaginal devices, parts of medical instruments).

Risk factors and pathophysiology



A vaginal foreign body typically results from the intentional or unintentional placement of an object into the vaginal canal.  In children, this may occur accidentally or in association with abuse.  In adults, it may be related to sexual activity, forgotten tampons, vaginal devices, or surgical materials.



A retained foreign body can lead to chronic irritation of the vaginal mucosa, causing inflammation, infection, and discharge.  Over time, a foreign body may erode into adjacent structures such as the bladder or rectum, potentially forming fistulas.  Chronic retention increases the risk for secondary infections, ulceration, granulation tissue formation, and, rarely, systemic infection.

Clinical presentation



The symptoms of a retained vaginal foreign body vary based on the object's size, composition, duration of retention, and whether infection is present.  Some cases may be asymptomatic, especially early on, whereas others may present with significant discomfort or complications.



Initial symptoms may include:



  • Malodorous vaginal discharge that is often profuse, purulent, or blood-stained (most common).
  • Vaginal bleeding.
  • Vaginal pruritus.
  • Dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency.


If left undetected for a prolonged period, a retained foreign body may lead to:



  • Vaginal ulceration.
  • Fistula formation.
  • Vaginal stenosis or scarring.
  • Systemic infection.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of a vaginal foreign body is primarily clinical, based on history and physical examination.  However, a history of insertion of an object into the vagina is not always available, particularly in children or in patients with cognitive impairment.  In children, a knee-chest or frog-leg position during physical examination is recommended; speculum examination should not be performed because it can result in significant discomfort and trauma due to the narrow vaginal introitus.  In adults, a speculum examination usually identifies the foreign object.

Laboratory evaluation and imaging studies



Laboratory evaluation is not usually necessary for diagnosis, but it can be helpful if infection, trauma, or other complications are suspected.  This can include wet mount microscopy, urinalysis, and cultures (eg, vaginal, blood).Imaging (eg, pelvic x-ray, MRI, CT scan) may be required if the foreign body is not easily visualized or if there is concern for complications (eg, abscess, fistula formation).



In rare cases, vaginoscopy (ie, the use of a small-diameter endoscope to evaluate the vaginal canal) may be used for direct visualization and removal.

Differential diagnosis



  • Vulvovaginitis:  Malodorous vaginal discharge may be present.  Vaginal foreign bodies may cause vulvovaginitis, and a foreign body should be suspected if the vulvovaginitis does not resolve with standard treatment.
  • Trauma or irritation:  Accidental trauma (eg, straddle injury, scratching), sexual abuse, or irritant contact dermatitis (eg, soaps, bubble baths, perfumed products) may cause vaginal discomfort, discharge, and irritation that present similarly to a retained vaginal foreign body.
  • Vaginal neoplasm:  Rhabdomyosarcoma (sarcoma botryoides) is a rare vaginal tumor in young girls.  The tumor often presents as a polypoid structure causing vaginal bleeding and a protruding mass.
  • Cervical or vaginal polyps:  These may lead to bleeding or blood-stained discharge as well as the sensation of something in the vagina.  In cases where there is associated inflammation, polyps may also cause persistent or malodorous vaginal discharge.
  • Urethral prolapse:  This can present as vaginal bleeding in prepubescent girls.  The circular red or purple mass at the urethral opening may be mistaken for a foreign body and may cause discomfort due to the exposed mucosa.

Management



Management involves the removal of the foreign body; however, the mechanism of removal depends on the ability to visualize the object, the type of foreign body, and patient comfort.  Small, easily visualized objects in both children and adults can typically be removed in the office.  Patients with a suspected foreign body that cannot be visualized or is associated with severe complications (eg, button battery causing burns) require an examination under anesthesia (eg, vaginoscopy) and foreign body removal.  Patient anxiety or lack of cooperation may also prohibit visualization, requiring examination under anesthesia.

Prognosis



The prognosis after removal of a vaginal foreign body is excellent in most cases because symptoms usually resolve rapidly once the object is removed.  However, delays in diagnosis or removal can lead to complications such as vaginal ulcers, fistula formation, or systemic infection.



The most concerning complication is toxic shock syndrome (TSS), a rare but potentially life-threatening complication that can occur with a retained vaginal foreign body (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
).  TSS is caused by the release of bacterial exotoxins that bind directly to class II major histocompatibility complexes (bypassing normal intracellular antigen processing), and activate T cells indiscriminately, leading to a massive release of inflammatory cytokines.  Clinical features include fever, shock (eg, hypotension, tachycardia), a diffuse macular rash, and multiorgan failure.  Treatment is with aggressive intravenous fluids (and sometimes vasopressors), removal of the retained foreign body, surgical debridement (in the setting of wound infection), and antibiotics.

Summary



Vaginal foreign bodies are objects that become lodged in the vaginal canal, either intentionally or unintentionally.  This condition is more common in pediatric patients due to a variety of causes ranging from accidental insertion to retained objects (eg, tampons, vaginal devices, parts of medical instruments).  Patients typically present with malodorous vaginal discharge and vaginal bleeding.  Diagnosis is clinical, and treatment is with removal of the foreign body.
